en_results: of the waves crashing against the rocky shores, I am reminded of
en_results_raw: of the waves crashing against the rocky shores, I am reminded of my lost love, Emily. Her smile, like the sun breaking through the morning fog, had a way of calming the turbulent waters of my soul. But now, it's just a distant memory, a bittersweet longing that haunts me still. The flames dance and flicker, casting shadows on the walls, a reminder of the warmth and comfort we once shared. I feel the weight of my loneliness, a heavy anchor that threatens to drag me under, but I hold on to the memories, the laughter, the tears, and the whispers we exchanged beneath the starry night sky. es_results_raw: de lana gruesa. El hombrecullo, que parecía un anciano, se acercó a Lennie con una mirada cansada. Llevaba un sombrero de fieltro en la mano y un bastón en la otra, y su rostro estaba marcado por las arrugas del tiempo. Se detuvo frente a Lennie y lo miró con una expresión de sorpresa, como si no hubiera esperado encontrar a alguien allí. Luego, con un movimiento lento y deliberado, se ajustó el chaleco y se dirigió hacia la habitación, murmurando algo para sí mismo. Lennie lo siguió con la mirada, intrigado por la presencia de este extraño hombre. El anciano se detuvo frente a una cómoda y comenzó a buscar algo entre sus cajones, mientras murmuraba para sí mismo. Lennie se acercó un poco más, intentando escuchar lo que estaba diciendo, pero el anciano no parecía notarlo. Finalmente, el anciano encontró lo que estaba buscando y se volvió hacia Lennie con una sonrisa cansada. "¿Puedo ayudarte en algo, amigo?" le preguntó con una voz ronca. Lennie se sorprendió por la pregunta y se detuvo en seco, sin saber qué responder. El anciano se acercó un poco más y continuó hablando, como si no hubiera esperado respuesta. "Soy el viejo abuelo de la casa, y he estado buscando algo que me había perdido hace años. ¿Puedes ayudarme a encontrarlo?" Lennie se sintió confundido, pero decidió que no tenía nada que perder, así que asintió con la cabeza y se acercó al anciano. Juntos, comenzaron a buscar en la habitación, revisando cada rincón y cada cajón, en busca del objeto perdido. Mientras buscaban, el anciano le contó a Lennie sobre su vida, sobre su familia y sus recuerdos, y Lennie se sintió atraído por la historia del anciano. Finalmente, después de lo que parecía horas de búsqueda, el anciano encontró lo que estaba buscando: un pequeño reloj de bolsillo con una cadena de plata. Lo sostuvo en la mano, sonriendo con una expresión de alegría, y Lennie se sintió contento por él. El anciano se despidió de Lennie y se dirigió hacia la puerta, pero antes de salir, se volvió hacia él y le dijo: "Gracias, muchacho. Me has ayudado mucho. Si alguna vez necesitas algo, no dudes en buscarme". Lennie asintió con la cabeza y se quedó mirando al anciano mientras se alejaba, sintiendo una sensación de conexión con él que no había sentido antes. El anciano desapareció en la oscuridad de la noche, dejando a Lennie solo en la habitación. Pero Lennie no se sintió solo, porque sabía que había encontrado un amigo en el anciano, y que siempre estaría allí para ayudarlo cuando lo necesitara.

en_results_raw: life for me. I need someone to talk to, someone who understands me. That's why I'm headed to the local saloon, where I heard the sheriff's daughter, Emily, might be working as a waitress. She's got spirit, that one, and I reckon she might be the kind of person I'm looking for. I've heard she's been looking for someone to help her with her horse, a stubborn mare that's been giving her trouble. Maybe I can help her with that, and in return, she can teach me more about the community and its people. I've been riding for hours, and the sun's starting to set, casting a golden glow over the dusty main street. I tie my horse to the hitching post outside the saloon and step inside, my eyes adjusting to the dim light. The patrons are a rough-looking bunch, but I spot Emily right away, her bright smile and sparkling eyes making her stand out in the crowd. I take a deep breath, feeling a mix of excitement and nervousness as I make my way over to her.

en_results_raw: “I don’t see no reason for it,” said Carlson. He went to his bunk, pulled his bag from underneath it and took out a Luger. He checked the chamber, ensuring it was clear, before tucking it back into his bag. The dim light of the small cabin cast eerie shadows on the walls as he sat back down, his eyes fixed on the door. The sound of the wind outside was the only noise that broke the silence, a constant reminder of the isolation they were in. The fire had burned down to embers, casting a faint glow over the room. He glanced at his watch, the ticking of the second hand the only sound that broke the stillness. It was almost midnight, and they were still waiting for a decision from the outside world. The tension was palpable, and Carlson couldn't help but wonder what the outcome would be. Would they be rescued, or would they be left to fend for themselves in this desolate place? The uncertainty was eating away at him, and he couldn't shake the feeling that they were running out of time.

De repente, se le ocurrió una idea y se dirigió hacia la puerta, pero se detuvo en seco cuando escuchó un ruido proveniente del pasillo. The previous owner, a grizzled old miner, left all his belongings behind, including a collection of dusty old books and a well-worn journal that might be worth something to the right collector. I've also heard rumors of a hidden room or two, but that's just speculation. Still, for six hundred bucks, it's a deal that's too good to pass up. George seemed hesitant, but I could tell he was tempted. He asked me to take him to see the cabin, and I agreed, knowing that once he saw it in person, he'd be hooked. As we walked through the dense forest, the trees grew taller and the underbrush thicker, casting deep shadows that made it difficult to see. Suddenly, a twig snapped, and George spun around, his eyes scanning the surrounding area, his face pale. I chuckled and told him it was probably just a rabbit, but he didn't seem convinced. We continued on, the silence between us growing thicker than the forest itself. When we finally emerged into a small clearing, the cabin came into view, its wooden boards weathered to a soft gray, the roof a deep, rich brown. George's eyes widened as he took in the sight, and I could see the wheels turning in his head. He was hooked, all right. Now it was just a matter of whether or not he'd be willing to take the plunge and make an offer.

en_first_half: Crooks, the negro stable buck, had his bunk in the harness room; a little shed that leaned off the wall of the barn. On one side of the little room there was a square four–paned window, and on the other, a narrow plank door leading into the barn. Crooks’ bunk was a long box filled with straw, on which his blankets were flung. On the wall by the window there were pegs on which hung broken harness in process of being mended; strips of new leather; and under the window itself a little bench for leather–working tools, curved knives and needles and balls of linen thread, and a small hand riveter. On pegs were also
en_second_half: pieces of harness, a split collar with the horsehair stuffing sticking out, a broken hame, and a trace chain with its leather covering split. Crooks had his apple box over his bunk, and in it a range of medicine bottles, both for himself and for the horses. There were cans of saddle soap and a drippy can of tar with its paint brush sticking over the edge. And scattered about the floor were a number of personal possessions; for, being alone, Crooks could leave his things about, and being a stable buck and a cripple, he was more permanent than the other men, and he had accumulated more possessions than he could carry on his back.

es_first_half: Crooks, el peón negro, tenía su camastro en el cuarto de los arneses, un pequeño cobertizo que sobresalía de la pared del granero. A un lado del cuartito había una ventana cuadrada, con cuatro vidrios, y en el extremo opuesto una estrecha puerta, hecha con tablas, que daba al granero. El camastro de Crooks era un largo cajón lleno de paja, sobre el cual estaban extendidas sus mantas. De unas clavijas fijadas a la pared, junto a la ventana, colgaban rotos arneses en trámite de ser arreglados y tiras de cuero nuevo. Bajo la misma ventana, una banqueta para las herramientas de talabartería, curvos cuchillos y agujas y ovillos de hebra de hilo, y un pequeño remachador de mano. Había latas de grasa para los arneses y una sucia lata de brea con su pincel asomando por el borde. en_results_raw: around the barn, his eyes fixed on the old, worn-out picture of a woman that hung on the wall, a picture that George had given him years ago. The picture was faded and torn, but Lennie still remembered the day George had given it to him, a day that had been filled with laughter and excitement. Lennie's eyes wandered back to the picture, and he began to reminisce about the good times he and George had shared, the times they had run away from their troubles and found freedom in the open fields and forests. He thought about the way the sunlight had danced through the trees, casting dappled shadows on the ground, and the way the wind had carried the sweet scent of wildflowers through the air. As he sat there, lost in thought, Lennie's eyes began to droop, and he let out a soft sigh, his chest rising and falling with a deep breath. The stillness of the barn was a balm to his weary soul, and for a moment, he felt at peace. But as the silence stretched out, Lennie's thoughts began to turn to the future, and the uncertainty that lay ahead. He thought about the farm they had left behind, and the life they had left behind, and the struggles they would face when they finally reached their destination. Lennie's eyes snapped back to the picture, and he felt a surge of determination run through him. He would make a new life for himself and George, a life free from the hardships and struggles of their past. He would work hard, and he would be proud of what he had accomplished. And as he sat there, surrounded by the quiet of the barn, Lennie felt a sense of hope that he had not felt in a long time.

She looked at the old man, who was sitting on the other side of the barn, his back against the wall, his eyes fixed on her with a deep sadness. She felt a pang of guilt for having been so cruel to him, for having taken advantage of his kindness and his loneliness. She remembered the way he used to talk to her, the way he used to look at her with a glint in his eye, and she felt a pang of regret for having taken him for granted. She got up slowly, her movements quiet and deliberate, and walked over to him, her eyes fixed on his face. The old man looked up at her, his eyes clouded with a mixture of sadness and resignation, but as he saw the look on her face, he smiled slightly, and for a moment, she saw a glimmer of the man he used to be. She sat down beside him, and they sat in silence for a moment, the only sound the creaking of the old barn, and the distant lowing of the cows. The tension between them was palpable, but it was a different kind of tension, one that was born of understanding and shared experience, rather than anger and resentment. As they sat there, the meanness and the plannings and the discontent seemed to fade away, and for a moment, they were just two old people, sitting together in the quiet of the barn, enjoying each other's company. El viento susurraba suavemente entre las hojas de los árboles, creando un canto sutil que acompañaba a Lennie en su reflexión solitaria. La brisa acariciaba su rostro, llevándole recuerdos de días idílicos en el campo, cuando la vida parecía más simple y el futuro, más prometedor. Pero ahora, la realidad se había impuesto, y Lennie se sentía abrumado por la responsabilidad de sus acciones, por la carga de sus decisiones. La sombra en la tierra parecía reflejar su estado de ánimo, oscura y profunda, como un pozo sin fondo que lo engullía. Sin embargo, en ese momento, Lennie se dio cuenta de que no estaba solo, que había algo más allá de sí mismo, algo que lo conectaba con el mundo que lo rodeaba.
